Research Paper Synergy of curvature and spin exchange in electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction on Co2@N6CNTs catalysts: A grand canonical density functional theory simulation Ming Chen Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Investigation Formal analysis Data curation a Zhi-rui Luo Writing – review & editing Formal analysis Data curation a De-bo Lin Writing – review & editing Formal analysis a Li-xin Han Writing – review & editing Formal analysis a Wen-xian Chen Writing – review & editing Formal analysis a ⁎ Gui-lin Zhuang Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization a b ⁎ a H-PSI Computational Chemistry Lab, Institute of Industrial Catalysis, State Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Green-Chemical Synthesis Technology, College of Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310032, PR China H-PSI Computational Chemistry Lab Institute of Industrial Catalysis State Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Green-Chemical Synthesis Technology College of Chemical Engineering Zhejiang University of Technology Hangzhou 310032 PR China aH-PSI Computational Chemistry Lab, Institute of Industrial Catalysis, State Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Green-Chemical Synthesis Technology, College of Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310032, PR China b Key Laboratory of Functional Molecular Solids Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Anhui Normal University, Wuhu 241002 Anhui, PR China Key Laboratory of Functional Molecular Solids Ministry of Education College of Chemistry and Materials Science Anhui Normal University Wuhu Anhui 241002 PR China bKey Laboratory of Functional Molecular Solids Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Anhui Normal University, Wuhu 241002 Anhui, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Herein, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were utilized to investigate the catalytic properties of Co2 diatom supported carbon nanotubes, focusing on synergy of curvature and spin exchange on electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) pathways. Specially, the ORR activity of Co2@N6CNTs across various tube diameters show that tube diameter influences the electronic structure, modifying magnetic moments, and producing a volcano-type trend in the 4e- ORR overpotential in the ferromagnetic (FM) state. Among them, (10,4) Co2@N6CNTs exhibit excellent 2e- ORR activity, with the overpotential significantly reduced from 0.14 V to 0.05 V by tuning the magnetic state from FM to antiferromagnetic (AFM). To further assess the impact of applied potential on reaction kinetics, grand canonical DFT simulation was used to simulate ORR energy evolution under constant potential. Moreover, Catalytic kinetic simulations reveal an exceptionally low activation barrier of 0.003 eV for *OOH protonation in the ferromagnetic 10-FM state, enhancing H2O2 formation. In the 10-AFM state, the formation of H2O2 from *OOH show ultralow barrier of 0.02 eV, indicating a strong preference for the 2e- pathway. These findings identify (10,4) Co2@N6CNTs as a highly efficient and magnetically responsive ORR catalyst, where the 10-AFM configuration exhibits outstanding 2e- ORR performance from both thermodynamic and kinetic perspectives, offering valuable theoretical insights into spin-regulated electrocatalysis. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Spin exchange Grand canonical DFT simulation Oxygen reduction reaction Data availability The data that supports the findings of this study are available within the article and its supplementary material. 1 Introduction In the last three decades, the escalating global energy demand, coupled with intensifying environmental challenges, has propelled the development of sustainable energy technologies to the forefront of scientific and industrial priorities [1] Electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) plays a critical role in proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) and the green electro-synthesis of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) [2–4] However, ORR suffers from inherently sluggish kinetics due to its complex multi-step electron-proton transfer mechanism, which severely limits the efficiency of electrocatalytic systems [5] Thus, achieving both high catalytic activity and selectivity for the desired reaction pathway, whether the four-electron (4e-) route for PEMFCs or the two-electron (2e-) route for H2O2 synthesis, is critical for scaling these technologies [6–8] Compared to high cost and scarcity of platinum-based catalysts[9–14], arguably most notable in this context is research on new-type electrocatalysts, e.g. metal oxidation, metal carbide [15–18] In this vein, metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) single-atom catalysts (SACs) have emerged as a revolutionary class of heterogeneous catalytic system. By atomically dispersing metal sites (e.g., Fe, Co) within nitrogen-doped carbon matrices, M-N-C SACs maximize atom utilization while offering tunable electronic structures, exceptional catalytic activity, and environmental compatibility [19–21] Beyond Fe-based systems, cobalt-doped N-C nanostructures have garnered attention for their unique structural and electronic properties. Notably, the curvature of carbon nanotube (CNT) supports in Co-N-C SACs profoundly influences catalytic behavior [22] Over the past decade, substantial progress has been made in tuning the chemical reactivity of M-C-N single-atom catalysts (SACs) through spin manipulation, leading to the discovery of a variety of intriguing correlations between magnetic properties and catalytic performance. Structurally, nanostructured electrocatalysts with controlled curvature (e.g., nanotubes, nanospheres, and defect-rich surfaces) exhibit unique electronic properties due to strain and coordination effects. However, previous studies have solely investigated the spin-state effect of isolated M-N4 sites on the ORR, while the synergistic interplay between spin exchange and curvature remains unexplored. Following GC-DFT computational method, herein, this study combines the nonlinear and nonlocal electrolyte model with spin-polarized DFT to systematically investigate the electrocatalytic ORR performance of Co2@N6CNTs in acidic environments. We systematically investigated the influence of tube diameter on catalyst stability, magnetic moment variations, and reaction pathways, elucidating the underlying mechanism by which magnetism and electronic structure synergistically modulate the ORR process. By employing the nonlinear and nonlocal solvent model, our simulations achieve improved agreement with experimental electrochemical conditions. These findings provide theoretical insights for the rational design of efficient and cost-effective electrocatalysts, and further extend the applicability of implicit solvent models in electrochemical research. 2 Computational details Spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP)[23] with the projector augmented-wave (PAW) method [24] The exchange-correlation interactions are treated using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the framework of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA)[25] for structural optimization. The plane wave basis set cutoff energy is set to 500 eV, and van der Waals interactions are corrected using the DFT-D3 method [26] The convergence criteria for energy and atomic forces are set to 10-5 eV per unit cell and 0.01 eV/Å, respectively. During the structural optimization, the PBE+U method based on the Hubbard model was applied to the localized 3d orbitals of the transition metals [27,28] The effective Coulomb interaction (Ueff = 3.3 eV)[29] for Co was applied to describe the 3d orbitals of the Co atoms. The Brillouin zone was sampled using the Monkhorst-Pack grid scheme. For structural optimization, a 1 × 1 × 4 k-point mesh was employed (the convergence test results are shown in Fig. S1), while a 1 × 1 × 8 k-point mesh was used for static self-consistent calculations and electronic structure calculations [30] In addition, both the MAGMOM and NUPDOWN parameters in the INCAR file were used for spin state settings. The formation energy E f of Co2@N6CNTs is defined:[31] (1) E f = E C o 2 @ N 6 C N T s − E C N T − 2 E C o − 6 E N + 10 E C Where E C o 2 @ N 6 C N T s is the energy of the Co-doped N-carbon nanotube, E C N T is the energy of the pure carbon nanotube, and E C o , E N and E C are the energies of the Co, N, and C atoms, respectively. The energy of a single atom E a t o m is calculated as follows: (2) E a t o m = E b u l k / m Where E b u l k refers to the bulk energy of a single element in a vacuum, and m is the number of atoms in the bulk system. The strain energy E s is an important parameter that reflects the structural stability of carbon nanotubes (CNTs). It is defined as the energy difference between the nanoflake and the nanotube. The formula for calculating the strain energy is as follows:[22] (3) E s = ( E n a n o s h e e t − E C N T ) / n The energy of the nanosheet is denoted as E n a n o s h e e t , the energy of the nanotube is denoted as E C N T , and n refers to the total number of atoms in the nanotube. To evaluate the binding strength between O2 and Co ions, the adsorption energy is calculated as follows:[32] (4) E a d s = E O 2 / C o 2 @ N 6 C N T s − E C o 2 @ N 6 C N T s − E O 2 Where E a d s represents the adsorption energy, E O 2 / C o 2 @ N 6 C N T s is the energy of O2 adsorbed on Co2@N6CNTs, E C o 2 @ N 6 C N T s is the energy of Co2@N6CNTs, and E O 2 is the single-point energy of O2. The Gibbs free energy is evaluated based on the Computational Hydrogen Electrode (CHE) model[33], where the free energy of proton-coupled electron pairs (H+/e+) is set as the free energy of 1/2 H2 at 0 V potential. (5) Δ G = Δ E − Δ E Z P E − T Δ S + Δ G U Typically, Δ E represents the electronic energy difference of the reaction; Δ E Z P E is the change in zero-point energy; T is taken as room temperature (298.15 K). The Δ S for the adsorption state can be obtained from vibrational frequencies via normal mode analysis. Δ G U is the free energy change associated with the electrode potential U. To evaluate the ORR activity, the limiting potential ( U L ) is calculated as follows:[34] (6) U L = − Δ G max / e The Δ G max represents the maximum free energy change along the entire reaction pathway. The overpotential η is calculated as follows: (7) η = U e q u i l i b r i u m − U L where U e q u i l i b r i u m is the equilibrium potential (for H2O2: 0.70 V; for H2O: 1.23 V). The reaction feasibility is discussed using the reaction energy barrier ( E a ) , which is calculated as follows: (8) E a = E T S − E I S where E T S is the transition state energy, and E I S is the initial state energy. Additionally, the potential magnetic phase transition properties of Co2@N6CNTs are crucial for practical applications. The phase transition temperature is determined using the mean field approximation, as described by the following equation: (9) T C = 2 3 k B Δ E N In the equation, Δ E represents the energy difference between magnetic states, N is the number of atoms, and k B is the Boltzmann constant. When Δ E = 0.07 eV, the Curie temperature ( T C ) is calculated to be 270.77 K. However, the exact phase transition temperature remains to be experimentally verified. To identify the effect of electric potential, grand canonical DFT (GC-DFT) calculations were performed using the VASPsol++ implemented VASP software. For VASPsol++, the nonlinear nonlocal model replicates the experimental "double hump" differential capacitance of electrified metal interfaces, prevents electrolyte leakage into sub-molecular spaces, and accurately predicts molecular solvation free energies, water self-ionization free energy, and the standard hydrogen electrode’s electron chemical potential [35] The ionic cavity radius was set to 4.0 Å and the electrolyte concentration was set to 1.0 mol/L, while all other parameters were kept at their default values. In GC-DFT, the constant-potential calculations were performed by varying the number of electrons. And the total free energy ( Φ ) is typically defined as: (10) Φ = A − μ N where A is the Helmholtz free energy, μ is the chemical potential of the electrons, and N is the total number of electrons. Furthermore, the conversion between U R H E and U S H E is given by the following equation:[36] (11) U R H E = U a p p l + U 0 + 0.059 p H Here, U R H E is the reversible hydrogen electrode potential, U a p p l is the applied potential, U 0 is the electrode potential under standard conditions, and p H is typically used to represent the acidity or alkalinity of the solution. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structures of Co2@N6CNTs The formation of the corresponding nanotube was achieved by curling the Co2@N6-sheet, with the curling direction defined by vectors a and b: Cv = ma + nb (m, n), where a and b represent the lattice vectors of the unit cell (as shown in Fig. 1a and d). To investigate the influence of tube diameter on catalytic performance, the b direction was fixed while varying the direction, focusing on (m, 4) nanotubes with m ranging from 6 to 14 in increments of 2. This produced five unit cells: (6, 4), (8, 4), (10, 4), (12, 4), and (14, 4). For example, Fig. 1a and 1b depict the (10, 4) C-sheet and (10, 4) CNTs, respectively, while Fig. 1d and 1e illustrate the (10, 4) Co2@N6-sheet and (10, 4) Co2@N6CNTs. Structures of CNTs and Co2@N6CNTs with varying diameters are shown in Fig. S2. Notably, constructing tubular models proves highly challenging for "m" values smaller than 6. For single-walled carbon nanotubes, diameters typically range from 0.4 to 3 nm [37] Thus, the minimum carbon nanotube diameter was set to 0.47 nm, corresponding to m = 6 with a 6 × 4 × 1 unit cell. For Co2@N6CNTs, two primary magnetic states exist: a ferromagnetic (FM) state, where both Co atoms exhibit upward spin alignment, and an antiferromagnetic (AFM) state, where one Co atom adopts an upward spin and the other a downward spin, yielding a net magnetic moment of zero. For clarity, the ferromagnetic state of (6, 4) Co2@N6CNTs is abbreviated as “6-FM” and the antiferromagnetic state as “6-AFM”. Similarly, (8, 4) Co2@N6CNTs are labeled “8-FM” and “8-AFM”, with analogous notation applied to other diameters. 3.2 Stability of Co2@N6CNTs, O2 adsorption and H species on Co2@N6CNTs Catalyst stability is fundamental to catalytic reactions. For dual-atom doped nanomaterials, evaluating their stability requires considering both the strain energy (Es) and formation energy (Ef). The specific calculation formulas for formation energy (Ef) and strain energy (Es) are provided in Eqs. (1) and (3). As shown in Fig. 2a , we calculated the formation energies of Co and N doped in carbon nanotubes with five different diameters. The results are all negative, indicating that these materials are thermodynamically stable. The calculation results of the formation energies show that as the diameter decreases, the formation energy becomes more negative, which may be attributed to the more significant deformation effects in materials with smaller diameters (as shown in Fig. S2 with images of materials with different diameters). Additionally, as shown in Fig. 2a, the strain energy decreases with increasing nanotube diameter, indicating improved structural stability. Fig. 2a shows that as the diameter increases, the Co-N and C-C bond lengths shorten, suggesting stronger internal bonding of the material. This trend is consistent with the changes in strain energy and supports the idea that increasing the diameter enhances the material’s stability. Additionally, catalysts with the Co@N4CNTs structure have also been reported in the study by Fei et al. [38] further demonstrating the experimental feasibility of this structure for future applications. To evaluate the kinetic stability of Co2@N6CNTs, we performed AIMD (ab initio molecular dynamics) simulations at 300 K with a simulation time of 10 ps and a time step of 1 fs. As seen in Fig. 2b, the results demonstrate that (10, 4) Co2@N6CNTs exhibit good kinetic stability at 300 K, with free energy fluctuations remaining within a reasonable range throughout the simulation, and no significant structural changes or instability observed, Comparable stability is observed for the other nanotube diameters as well (see Fig. S3). These results indicate that Co2@N6CNTs possess good thermodynamic, structural, and kinetic stability, offering theoretical support for their potential application in catalytic reactions. In addition, considering the competition between the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), and the fact that *H generated during HER serves as the key hydrogen source for ORR, we performed a detailed analysis of the adsorption energies of *H and *O2 (see Fig. 2). Among the five nanotubes with different diameters, whether in the ferromagnetic (FM) or antiferromagnetic (AFM) state, the binding energy of *H is greater than 0 eV, while the adsorption energy of *O2 is less than -0.4 eV. This indicates that *H does not compete with *O2 for the catalytic sites. Furthermore, the Gibbs free energy for the HER is higher than that for ORR, demonstrating the excellent HER inhibition performance of Co2@N6CNTs. 3.3 4e- pathway of ORR under the CHE model The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) typically involves two main pathways: the two-electron pathway and the four-electron pathway. In the two-electron process, O2 adsorbs and reacts with two H⁺ ions, ultimately forming H2O2. In the four-electron process, O2 adsorbs and reacts with four H⁺ ions, being reduced to H2O. The four-electron pathway includes two distinct mechanisms: in the dissociative mechanism, O2 dissociates on the catalyst surface, forming two O atoms, with H+ ions subsequently adsorbing onto one of the O atoms, leading to the reduction to H2O; in the associative mechanism, H+ ions first adsorb onto the O2 molecule, forming *OOH intermediates, which are then further reduced to H2O [39] The 4e- ORR reaction mechanism was assumed to follow the four-step associative mechanism represented by (12) O 2 ( g ) + H + + e − ⇌ * O O H (13) * O O H + H + + e − ⇌ * O + H 2 O ( l ) (14) * O + H + + e − ⇌ * O H (15) * O H + H + + e − ⇌ * H 2 O ( l ) The 2e- reaction pathway producing H2O2 is (16) O 2 ( g ) + H + + e − ⇌ * O O H (17) * O O H + H + + e − ⇌ H 2 O 2 ( l ) The 4e- ORR and 2e- ORR are two competing reactions in electrochemical systems, and they strongly depend on the type of O2 adsorption. O2 adsorption on metal surfaces is typically classified into three types (Fig. S4): one end-on type (Pauling-type) and two side-on types (Griffiths-type and Yeager-type). For end-on (Pauling-type) adsorption of O2, both 2e- ORR and 4e- ORR are possible. In contrast, side-on adsorption of O2 facilitates the cleavage of the O-O bond, which may lead to a higher selectivity for the 4e- ORR, while the 2e- ORR becomes less likely. Our results show that O2 adsorbs in a Pauling-type manner on the surface of Co2@N6CNTs across all nanotube diameters (see Fig. S5), with no O-O bond cleavage observed. Therefore, the first O2 dissociation pathway is ruled out, and only the associative mechanism in the 4e- pathway and the 2e- reaction pathway need to be further investigated. Along the four-electron ORR pathway (Fig. 3 ), Co2@N6CNTs display a strong dependence on nanotube diameter and magnetic state. Across all investigated diameters, ferromagnetic configurations consistently exhibit superior catalytic activity compared to their antiferromagnetic (AFM) counterparts. Specifically, the 10-FM structure delivers the lowest overpotential of 0.39 V, which is 0.09 V lower than that of 10-AFM (0.48 V), highlighting the critical role of magnetic ordering in promoting catalytic kinetics. In FM systems, the overpotential shows a non-monotonic response to increasing tube diameter, initially decreasing and then increasing. This trend aligns closely with changes in the magnetic moment of the Co active sites, which reaches a maximum of 1.34 μB in 10-FM and gradually decreases in 12-FM and 14-FM (Fig. 3a, c). The observed correlation supports the high-spin-state-enhanced *O2 activation mechanism reported by Yu et al. [40] emphasizing the importance of spin-state modulation in tuning adsorption energetics and catalytic pathways. Further insights from reaction energy analysis (Table S1) reveal that variations in tube diameter induce a shift in the potential-limiting step (PDS). For small-diameter tubes, the PDS corresponds to *OH hydrogenation (*OH + H → * + H2O), whereas in larger-diameter tubes, it transitions to O2 activation (*O2 + H → *OOH). This shift arises from a systematic weakening in *OOH adsorption, with adsorption energies decreasing from -1.04 eV for 6-FM and -0.74 eV for 8-FM to -0.67 eV for 10-FM. This trend exemplifies the Sabatier principle, where optimal catalytic activity emerges from a balance between adsorption strength and activation barrier [41] We further calculated the Bader charge distribution of key intermediates during the reaction on the 10-FM configuration (see Fig. S6) to gain deeper insight into the ORR process. These results demonstrate that nanotube diameter regulates both local spin states and intermediate adsorption behavior in a synergistic manner, ultimately dictating catalytic performance and offering a rational strategy for the design of advanced ORR catalysts through spin-structure engineering. To further elucidate the origin of magnetic moment differences, we systematically examined the local magnetic moment of the Co single atom at the active site in ferromagnetic configurations across five distinct nanotube diameters (see Table S2). The spin polarization, defined as the difference between the number of spin-up and spin-down electrons (Δρspin), were also identified. As shown in Fig. S7, Δρspin is 0.22 for 6-FM and 0.15 for 10-FM, suggesting that the discrepancy in magnetic moment is primarily driven by variations in the spin state distribution. These results indicate that changes in nanotube diameter induce modifications to the local electronic structure[22], particularly the redistribution of spin density, thereby modulating the magnetic characteristics of the Co active site. Therefore, it is proposed that the evolution of the magnetic moment modulates the adsorption strength of key reaction intermediates, ultimately determining the observed trends in overpotential (η) across different configurations. 3.4 2e- pathway of ORR under the CHE model As shown in Fig. 4 , under the 2e- pathway, the two-electron overpotential in the ferromagnetic state decreases with increasing nanotube diameter, whereas in the antiferromagnetic state, the overpotential first decreases and then increases, with 10-AFM exhibiting the lowest overpotential (0.05 V). To further analyze the catalytic performance in the antiferromagnetic state, we investigated the adsorption energy of the *OOH intermediate on Co2@N6CNTs. According to Table S3, the adsorption energies of *OOH on 6-AFM and 8-AFM are -0.79 eV and -0.80 eV, respectively, while for 10-AFM, 12-AFM, and 14-AFM, they are -0.71 eV, -0.70 eV, and -0.72 eV, respectively. The stronger adsorption of *OOH on 6-AFM and 8-AFM increases the thermodynamic barrier of the *OOH + H → * + H2O2 step, hindering the progress of this reaction step. In contrast, for 10-AFM, 12-AFM, and 14-AFM, changes in the electronic structure induced by varying the nanotube diameter result in lower overpotentials. Projected Density of States (PDOS) analysis further reveals the conductivity and the bonding strength between the catalyst and the intermediate [42] As shown in Fig. S8, the Co1 active site density of states in 10-AFM better aligns with that of *OOH, significantly enhancing catalytic performance. Therefore, with increasing nanotube diameter, the two-electron oxygen reduction reaction performance improves significantly, with the optimal overpotential of η10-AFM = 0.05 V, the overpotential for the 10-FM state is 0.14 V, indicating that the transition from ferromagnetic to antiferromagnetic states reduces the overpotential by 0.09 V. 3.5 Effect of applied potential on catalytic property for ORR To investigate the effects of applied potential and pH on the reaction, GC-DFT method was utilized to simulate the implicit solvent environment. Based on the excellent performance of (10,4) Co2@N6CNTs in the CHE model, we focused on this tube diameter for further analysis. Fig. 5 presents the grand canonical or Gibbs free energy diagrams of the ORR reaction were calculated using both the CHE and GC-DFT, respectively. In the GC-DFT calculations, the lowest overpotential for the 4e- ORR pathway is η10-FM = 0.29 V, indicating a preference for the 4e- pathway. Compared to the CHE model, the ORR intermediates calculated using GC-DFT calculations show more stable energies, likely due to the CHE model’s omission of electrochemical interface dielectric effects. A similar trend was reported in the study by Feng et al. [43] where the ORR intermediates calculated using GC-DFT method showed more stable energies than those obtained with the CHE method. As shown in Fig. 5a, during the ORR process, the energy of both the catalyst and the reaction intermediates initially increases and then decreases with increasing voltage. To investigate the impact of voltage on the reaction energy, we calculated the ΔΩ for each step of the 4e- ORR and fitted the ΔΩ values for the same reaction step at different voltages. The fitting results and corresponding errors are shown in Table S4 and Table S5. As shown in Fig. 5b, when the voltage is below 0.73 V, the PDS occurs primarily in the *O+H → *OH process. However, When the USHE is between 0.73 V and 1 V, the PDS shifts to *OOH+H → *O+H2O. The constant-potential calculations help in understanding the variation of the reaction energy with voltage. The influence of pH on the ORR process is also significant. As shown in Fig. 5c, we calculated the energy of the catalyst and reaction intermediates as a function of pH (U = 0 V vs. RHE) and fitted the ΔΩ values at seven different pH levels, with the fitting results and errors provided in Table S6 and Table S7. As shown in Fig. 5d, when pH < 1.57, the PDS corresponds to the *+O2 +H→ *OOH process; whereas when 1.57 ≤ pH < 13, the potential-determining step shifts to *O+H → *OH. 3.6 Activity and selectivity of ORR on Co2@N6CNTs Regarding the selectivity between 2e- and 4e- ORR pathways, it is widely recognized that a limiting potential closer to the equilibrium potential (0.70 V for 2e- ORR and 1.23 V for 4e- ORR vs. SHE) corresponds to a lower overpotential and higher catalytic activity [16] As shown in Fig. S9, both the overpotentials and limiting potentials for 2e- and 4e- ORR vary significantly with tube diameter and magnetic state. Specifically, the lowest overpotential for 2e- ORR is η10-AFM = 0.05 V, while that for 4e- ORR is η10-FM = 0.39 V, indicating that the (10,4) Co2N6CNTs system favors the 2e- pathway to produce H2O2. As further illustrated in Fig. S9a, the overpotential for 2e- ORR in the FM state is 0.14 V, which decreases to 0.05 V upon switching to the AFM state, highlighting its potential as a high-performance 2e- ORR catalyst. Based on the thermodynamic performance of the (10,4) Co2@N6CNTs system, a systematic kinetic investigation was further carried out. Transition states were identified using the climbing image nudged elastic band (CINEB) method [44,45], and the activation energy barriers for the associated elementary steps are shown in Fig. S10 and Fig. S11. As shown in Fig. 6a , after the formation of the *OOH intermediate, the reaction can proceed along two distinct pathways. In the 10-FM state, the protonation of *OOH to form H2O2 has a minimal energy barrier of 0.003 eV, significantly lower than the 0.43 eV barrier required for the conversion of *O and *H into H2O along the 4e- pathway. This considerable energy difference indicates that the 10-FM state preferentially selects the 2e- pathway to generate H2O2. As shown in Fig. 6b and Fig. S11b, it is revealed that in the 10-AFM state, the protonation of OOH to form H2O2 proceeds with a minimal activation barrier of 0.02 eV, this favorable kinetic feature further supports the preference for the 2e- ORR pathway, promoting selective H2O2 production. In contrast, for the 4e- ORR pathway, *OOH dissociates into *O, followed by sequential protonation steps to form *OH and ultimately H2O, with corresponding energy barriers of 0.10 eV, 0.32 eV, and 0.44 eV. The barrier (0.44 eV) of rate-determining step is still higher than those in the 2e- ORR pathway, indicating stronger kinetic limitations for the 4e- pathway. Furthermore, at low overpotential conditions, the 4e- pathway may face additional restrictions due to theoretical potential effects, while the 2e- ORR pathway remains highly selective. Although microscopic kinetic analysis based on the climbing image nudged elastic band (CINEB) method can effectively estimate the energy barriers and parameters of elementary reaction steps, it is insufficient to comprehensively predict the complex dynamic catalytic behaviors under realistic operating conditions. Kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) simulations, which can accurately capture the transient evolution of surface reactions on catalysts[46–48], have become an important complementary tool for kinetic studies. In the future, closely integrating DFT calculations with KMC simulations in catalytic systems is expected to provide deeper insights into the dynamic evolution of electrochemical reaction mechanisms under practical operating conditions. Conclusion In this study, we employed the DFT calculations to systematically investigate the synergy of curvature and spin exchange of Co2@N6CNTs on ORR performance. CHE model calculations indicated that the ORR predominantly follows the 2e- ORR pathway, where the 10-AFM Co2@N6CNTs features 2e- ORR performance as low as -0.05 V. The changes in nanotube diameter leads to modifications in the electronic structure, which in turn affect the magnetic moment distribution of Co atoms, and by modulating the adsorption strength of *OOH, cause fluctuations in the 2e- ORR overpotential. To further explore the effects of the applied potentials and pH on the reaction, GC-DFT methods was employed to simulate the trends of ORR barriers with varying voltage and pH. Further kinetic analysis revealed that, in the 2e- ORR pathway, the protonation of *OOH in the ferromagnetic 10-FM state requires overcoming a barrier of only 0.003 eV, significantly promoting the generation of H2O2. In contrast, in the antiferromagnetic 10-AFM state, the formation of *HOOH from *OOH proceeds with a low energy barrier of 0.02 eV, further suggesting that the 10-AFM state also favors the selective 2e- pathway. The results suggest that by tuning the spin state from 10-FM to 10-AFM, the 2e- overpotential can be significantly lowered from 0.14 V to 0.05 V, accompanied by an ultralow barrier of 0.02 eV. This study highlights Co2@N6CNTs as promising magnetically responsive catalysts for hydrogen peroxide production and provides valuable theoretical insight for the rational design of efficient and economical electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: Herein, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were utilized to investigate the catalytic properties of Co2 diatom supported carbon nanotubes, focusing on synergy of curvature and spin exchange on electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) pathways. Specially, the ORR activity of Co2@N6CNTs across various tube diameters show that tube diameter influences the electronic structure, modifying magnetic moments, and producing a volcano-type trend in the 4e- ORR overpotential in the ferromagnetic (FM) state. Among them, (10,4) Co2@N6CNTs exhibit excellent 2e- ORR activity, with the overpotential significantly reduced from 0.14 V to 0.05 V by tuning the magnetic state from FM to antiferromagnetic (AFM). To further assess the impact of applied potential on reaction kinetics, grand canonical DFT simulation was used to simulate ORR energy evolution under constant potential. Moreover, Catalytic kinetic simulations reveal an exceptionally low activation barrier of 0.003 eV for *OOH protonation in the ferromagnetic 10-FM state, enhancing H2O2 formation. In the 10-AFM state, the formation of H2O2 from *OOH show ultralow barrier of 0.02 eV, indicating a strong preference for the 2e- pathway. These findings identify (10,4) Co2@N6CNTs as a highly efficient and magnetically responsive ORR catalyst, where the 10-AFM configuration exhibits outstanding 2e- ORR performance from both thermodynamic and kinetic perspectives, offering valuable theoretical insights into spin-regulated electrocatalysis.
